title: City SDK – Smart City Services bases on Open Source Linked Open Data API’s
segmentation: Thank you for the interesting presentations so far.
I think I hope my presentation will have some relevance for some of your work as well.
I will tell you about the EU program City SDK, the city software or city service development kits, and it's a project by 23 organizations in Europe.

Nine countries in eight cities that together wants to make a service delivery kit service development kit for cities to make it easier for cities to share their open data, but also for developers to make use of that open data because they will know for sure that the open data isn't used in their standardized way.
To make it easier for applications to be written for one city and then transported to another city.
Currently this is very hard because the formats and the APIs, if there are some, are.
Very well to say the least.
Sometimes they are totally inconsistent.
Sometimes there not described, so it's very hard for a developer in the city to even make an application for the city that he lives in.

Then again, if a developer makes an application for the city, it's mostly not sustainable in the sense that it will be too small to make enough business out of it for him to be able to make a living, and that is hard.

It's hard both for the cities, because they don't get the applications that they could if they could take applications for other cities in their places, it's hard for the developers because as I said, they cannot scale their applications and also bad for the citizens that have no way to get to the best applications there are, because they will.
Probably not be valid for their own cities.
And that's why together, within our consortium, two years ago, we set out to make certain city APIs that will be put on top of the existing system.
So the people in the city don't have to change all of their legacy systems.
But in certain domains, they can put our city SDK on top of it.
It's open source and it will allow other people to very easily get ahold of the data that the city has, and this will make scaling much more.
Armouring simple.
And maybe a subtext that we have.
I come from a nonprofit organization called Back Society and we develop technology for social innovation and we try to engage a large network of developers and to help them to do their work better.

So we hope that by doing this kind of exercise is there will be a stronger bond between the people being in the city, local governments and the large developer community that typically is available in the city.
We do this by building the City SDK ecosystem.
It starts from the platform services and interfaces of open data that the cities already have.
It's introduces a middle layer, unified open City interfaces that we made through certain pilots.
Because you cannot do that in all domains together at the same time, you have to take a certain domain and then go deep into that on and so another domain as well and we chose three domains for that.
Then we built a certain project pilots and the pilots showed us and showed all the involved people.
The potential of this kind of work and it also informed the API so they could be my better.
And then we engaged the city developer community.
And we tried to interface between the people, the city officials and the development community to come up with interesting application.
We have a large coverage by now and it's growing.
We started in these eight different cities an at this moment we are building Association.
The project is almost finished to take on the things that came out of it and bring it further and we have interest from about 5 to 10 different cities as well.
So maybe if you're interested please let me know.
We worked to be able to come up with a meaningful API.
We worked in a special fashion.
We worked with pilots in a certain city.
We did the mobility pilot for example in Amsterdam and then we tried to replicate the exact same implementation to another city, in this case Istanbul and Lisbon.
So by forcing ourselves to actually do the trick, once we made sure that it's doable, and by that we made sure that now you can do it to other cities as well.
The first topic we took is smart participation.
It's how to get meaningful information from citizens and take it back to city governments.
And the simplest use case to take there was open 311.
I don't know if you are aware of that system.
Is the system developed in the United States for easily getting information from citizens?
For example, about holding the street or other things that needs to be fixed and put them back into the back ends of the cities.
Currently, for example, in the Netherlands there are few as a means to try to set up such services, and they did so for each city again and again, which is.
A lot of work, and it's not so helpful for citizens in general and in this way you can just make it once very good and you can deploy it at all cities that implements this specific API.

We did also for tourism, Nancy, the first speaker told us how important tourism is for City of our for a country like Greece, I think tourism is important for all of us and tourists typically don't want to have an application for all the cities that they visit, but they won't.

Application that will work everywhere or at least several ones, and that's why we made it more easy to gather all kinds of information about that have vaguely a relationship to tourism and to put him in the API.

It's real time, and people can have, for example, real time information about where to where to go tonight, but also where to park the car and where to eat before and everything is integrated well, it can be integrated based on the API.
The pilot that I know most about this, the smart mobility, because that's the one where our organization was to work.
Package leader for.

It's maybe the most complex one because it wrote what it actually wants to do is to take all the different layers of information about traffic, and there's huge things that are relevant to traffic and to put them in a single API that all people can use to make applications on that will then scale throughout.
That's what we did.
First of all, we did analysis of what kind of traffic?
Well, what kind of data you might possibly have, and as you can see here, it's actually huge.
It's also what, for example, where do the people who clean the cars in the streets?
If you want to have a really good planner, for example, you need to have very accurate information about what happened exactly now, so it's a very huge task.
To start off.
To do this, we used of course linked open data and we started with Openstreetmap because Openstreetmap is, as you probably know, far more reliable than this.
For example Google Interface, and we put all.
The layers on top that we could find.
Currently it's it's a project process that is rather time consuming because you have to make sure that these layers are aligned.
Since they have to be aligned so you know exactly that a certain point in space has all the relevant data attached to it that you can possibly have.

Well, we did so and now it's very easy for developers to just look at the street segment or look at the road or look at a parking place, look at something and just to get all the relevant data that is there now.
This is knew also two cities because cities they started with open data mostly by just taking the PDF's or the CS fees or any data source.
They had very static ones and put them somewhere then with links that you could not refer to consistently.

Of course they started, but what we need now to make meaningful applications is to have real time, reliable information that we can trust and this is a way to have these governments think about how to do that an all.
Offices facilitate them in doing that because we actually built an open source standard set of interfaces based on the TFs and Surface.
Several other standards that you can implement on top of your existing systems and then allow everybody else to build.
That built on top.

This is graphically how it looks like what is what I think is interesting about our system is that it not only is a linear thing that we have the data and you have the apps, but the City of Amsterdam has commissioned another API to be put on top of our city surface development kits dealing only with making very accurate predictions about barking actually and also about travel times towards parking spaces.
And travel times from the parking space to the space that you want to go.
So that's a specific use case that you need specific technology for, and you can easily plug that.
It's a stackable system.
Actually, we take the metaphor, the software metaphor to the city, and implementing that actually works.
Talk more about that, but no, everything is linked.
Open data that is in the system.

We have more than 60 datasets across the different cities, and as you can see from this diagram, some cities are faster than others, but gradually this is a sheet from my guess two or three months ago, so it greatly it shifts, and there's more and more available.
An we you can look to the website, City SDK drafted or and see extensive description.
As I told you we come from we start with people that actually reuse the data.
So we want to make reuse as simple as easy as possible and we document everything we do.
For example, by implementing this viewer that will allow people to very quickly look at the.
I don't know who is developer, but developers love things like this of course, and then easily to see a graphical interface of what you can do and what you have to do and how it gets out.
So it's very easy to start to understand the rather complex data and the datasets there.
Weather in based on that, several applications are made.
We made a very simple demo application about the age of all the buildings in the Netherlands that suddenly struck on and many people have seen.
We made an open data globe that is showing the real time information on the system and it's showing that for all the cities that are connected at this moment.

We've done some work on making travel applications on hacking based in hackathons, for example in Manchester they made the Greater Manchester Real time scheduling application that shows you about the real time scheduling aspects of the fate of the public transport several games, another Xanax.
I guess you can now imagine that if they made it in Manchester it will be very easy to port that or Amsterdam.
Actually, it's just trivial.
I told you about the API built on top of our API, so this is the parking API that is built.
So I told you before, so it's very easy to have done developers of end applications work with parking information.

And as a final showcase, we are building a city dashboards and the city dashboard will allow rather easy access to the key datasets that we have about all the cities and we want to implement this also a way to visualize what were the intentions of the government.
So if they have certain goals that we want to achieve and see real time how far they are reaching those goals are.
Almost finished, this is the fact sheet.
So you can see who to contact with May.
I will be here.
So if you have any more questions about this or want to join the ecosystem, please let me know.
